X.T: Bruce Schneier
The Daily Swig
The Update Framework
gittuf
Setuid Demystified

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A thorough analysis of setuid: the system calls, divergence between Solaris, Linux and FreeBSD, its pitfalls…

X.T: Spies Among Us

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This is a basic presentation of the Trojan horse software which report private data to some miscreant companies.

X.T: The Linux Security "State of the Union"

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A list of some of the projects trying to improve Linux security. This list is interesting, but it misses too many projects and the article is much too optimistic: no Linux deficiency is described, the projects are not criticised.

X.T: W3C criticizes antirobot tests

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The issues with the visual "Turing tests" used to impede bots of exploiting a Web service.

X.T: The Journey from Poacher to Gamekeeper

ARTICLE.COMMENT: When you turn from a black hat into a white hat, people tend to be suspicious.

X.T: Open Source Security: Still a Myth

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author explains why open-source software is probably less secure than proprietary software. I agree that the "many eyeballs" is wrong for most open source code, only the most important applications have their code reviewed by several persons, but I also believe that most software companies are not allocating real resources to improve the security of their products.

X.T: A Sci-Fi Future Awaits the Court
X.ST: As chief justice of the Supreme Court, John Roberts will preside over cases pitting individual privacy against technologies we can only dream of today. How he will judge them is anyone's guess. Commentary by Bruce Schneier.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: JohnRobert, future technologies and the "right to privacy".

X.T: Real Story of the Rogue Rootkit

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Why have the security companies not reported and fought against the Sony’s rootkit?

X.T: Data Mining 101: Finding Subversives with Amazon Wishlists

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some data mining in the data that Amazon let us look at…

X.T: Anonymity Won't Kill the Internet
Anonymity Won't Kill the Internet

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An answer to KevinKelly who pretends that anonymity is a bad idea for Internet and will be replaced by pseudo-anonymity (where the real name of the person is known by the site): the issue is in fact all about accountability, pseudo-anonymity is the same as no anonymity.

X.T: Big Risks Come in Small Packages

ARTICLE.COMMENT: It is easier and easier to be stolen of a huge amount of data. In some cases, the solution, once a device has been stolen, could be to remotely delete the data.

X.T: The Anti-ID-Theft Bill That Isn't
X.ST: Congress is debating a bill that would follow state laws in forcing companies to come clean on security breaches. But Washington's version would help criminals more than victims. Commentary by Bruce Schneier.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: US Congress votes a law for personal data protection that will pre-empt the state laws which are stronger.

X.T: Everyone Wants to 'Own' Your PC

ARTICLE.COMMENT: More and more people are trying to get some control on everyone’s PC: DRM, spyware, adware, security features that does not work against some companies products…

X.T: The Eternal Value of Privacy
X.ST: Supporters of wholesale government surveillance are fond of saying that only the guilty should be worried about spying. Let's put that spurious argument out to pasture once and for all. Commentary by Bruce Schneier.

X.T: The Eternal Value of Privacy

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Schneier tries to explain why we should try to protect our privacy. But I find this article less convincing that his usual production, even if I fully agree with the message.

X.T: Make Vendors Liable for Bugs
X.ST: Security is at its best when those with the capability to fix security holes are also the ones who get hurt by them. Surprisingly, this isn't the way it works now. Commentary by Bruce Schneier.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A clever way to use the customer to control the cash register employee, how the ATM fraud has been managed in the UK vs. the US, and software companies should be liable for the security defects of their products.

X.T: Hacking Computers Over USB

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Put a Trojan on a USB key and drop this one on a parking lot…

X.T: Google's Click-Fraud Crackdown

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to know if the visitor of your site is a human or a robot?

X.T: Lessons From the Facebook Riots

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Facebook has learned the hard way that it is not the real secrecy of privacy that matters, but the its perception.

X.T: Why Microsoft is wrong on Vista security

ARTICLE.COMMENT: McAfee explains that Microsoft impedes them to properly implement an antivirus in Vista.

X.T: The Architecture of Security

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Architectural artefacts remain much longer that the risk they were design to solve.

X.T: My Data, Your Machine

ARTICLE.COMMENT: It is difficult to protect something which in the hands of the attacker.

X.T: MySpace Passwords Aren't So Dumb

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Young users are better at choosing good passwords.

X.T: Secustick gives false sense of security

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The "secure" Secustick USB key appears to be totally broken.

X.T: How Security Companies Sucker Us With Lemons

ARTICLE.COMMENT: GeorgeAkerlof’s theory (markets where the sellers have more information than the buyers result in being dominated by bad products) can be applied to security products.

X.T: Reverse engineering techniques to find security bugs: A...

ARTICLE.COMMENT: AlexSotirov explains the tools he is using to analyse Microsoft patches. He also describes the security features of Windows and how to try to bypass them.

X.T: Could a Caveman Do It? The Surprising Potential of Simple Attacks

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author explains that some simple brute force attacks can break a system. He gives the example of a wireless ad hoc network. The idea is interesting. But its conclusions (attacking 10% of the nodes may degrade the network performance from 10% to 60%) are not really convincing.

X.T: Are Internet users at risk?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some analysis on the spread of malicious Web pages, the percentage of vulnerable Web users, and Microsoft and Apple efficiency to fix security bugs.

X.T: The Xbox 360 Security System and its Weaknesses

ARTICLE.COMMENT: After describing the Xbox security gaps, how they have been fixed in the Xbox 360, MichaelSteil describes one of the security holes found in that new release.

X.T: How to Steal a Botnet and What Can Happen When You Do

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How the UCSB hijacked the Torpig botnet and an analysis of the data they were able to get from this.

X.T: Behind the China attacks on Google (FAQ)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some little information on the December attack of Google and other Silicon Valley companies. The Chinese government is suspected.

X.T: New Attack Uses Internet Explorer's Own Features Against It
X.ST: Microsoft investigating threat, considering patch, or offering guidance for protection

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Another IE security hole: combining URL Security Zones and file-sharing protocol to access local files.

X.T: Google And Facebook's Privacy Illusion
X.ST: These companies and others say privacy erosion is inevitable--but they're making it so.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Market forces push companies to offer less and less privacy, and people gets used to this situation.

X.T: Black Hat Spam SEO

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of search spam used to attract Internet users and infect them with malware.

X.T: Surviving a Hack

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A guy who got his Joomla! site hacked give some basic advice on how to restore it.

X.T: TechEd 2013: Live Demonstration: Hacker Tools You Should Know and Worry About

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some quick demos of some hacking tools.

X.T: Why It's Important to Publish the NSA Programs

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The efforts of NSA to ensure that they can eavesdrop on everyone’s communication is degrading the security of the US.

X.T: Eliminate banner grabbing in Apache Tomcat
X.ST: Don't let your Tomcat installation be a cyber snitch

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to configure Apache Tomcat so it does not reveal its version. But the last screenshot still shows it…

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to ensure that your vote is properly counted while it cannot be determined who you voted for.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An explanation of the danger of a poor session secret and how to properly manage it.

X.T: OSS-Fuzz: Five Months Later, and Rewarding Projects

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The current status of OSS-Fuzz and Google will offer rewards for onboarding new projects.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some advice on how to become a security researcher.

X.T: Triton is the world’s most murderous malware, and it’s spreading
X.ST: The rogue code can disable safety systems designed to prevent catastrophic industrial accidents. It was discovered in the Middle East, but the hackers behind it are now targeting companies in North America and other parts of the world, too.

X.T: Fatal Flaw Weakens RFID Passports
